title: How to Make Mirrors by Silvering Glass

steps.title: Get 1 gram of silver nitrate and 1 gram (0.035 oz) of sodium hydroxide in separate containers and add enough water to both to dissolve them.
steps.content: Get 1 gram of silver nitrate and 1 gram (0.035 oz) of sodium hydroxide in separate containers and add enough water to both to dissolve them. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Mix the two solutions together.
steps.content: Mix the two solutions together. A black precipitate of silver oxide will form.

steps.title: Add ammonia until the precipitate completely redissolves.
steps.content: Add ammonia until the precipitate completely redissolves. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Add 4 grams of sugar and stir until dissolved.
steps.content: Add 4 grams of sugar and stir until dissolved.

steps.title: Place your article you want to silver into the solution, or pour the solution into a tray containing your article (for larger articles like glass panes)
steps.content: Place your article you want to silver into the solution, or pour the solution into a tray containing your article (for larger articles like glass panes)

steps.title: GENTLY heat the solution but DO NOT let it boil.
steps.content: GENTLY heat the solution but DO NOT let it boil. Boiling tears the silver off the surface

steps.title: Eventually the solution will turn to a cream color and your article is now silvered, take it out and wipe off the silver from where you don't want it.
steps.content: Eventually the solution will turn to a cream color and your article is now silvered, take it out and wipe off the silver from where you don't want it.

steps.title: If the silver is really stuck to places you don't want it you can apply hydrochloric acid.
steps.content: If the silver is really stuck to places you don't want it you can apply hydrochloric acid.
